author: Anton Kratiuk
title: Tekken 8 producer has promised to fix all the fighting game's problems that were discovered in the demo | Gagadget.com
text:
In December, gamers got the opportunity to get acquainted with the demo of Tekken 8 fighting game.
Fans of the universe with pleasure joined the familiarisation with the new part of Tekken and were generally satisfied with the work done by Bandai Namco.
Here's What We Know Of course, not without remarks. Users found a number of problems that need to be fixed before the release of the game.
Tekken producer Katsuhiro Harada thanked gamers for the critical feedback and assured that the company will certainly listen to them and in the remaining time before the release to fix everything that can.
The TEKKEN8 demo, which is now available, has attracted very positive feedback and preorders are steadily increasing. Thank you all for your support.
And we will be fixing the problems found in the demo version in the full product version. Please wait for a while for the release.
- Katsuhiro Harada (@Harada_TEKKEN) January 5, 2024
When We Can Expect It Tekken 8 will be released on 26 January 2024. The fighting game will be released on MS, PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series.
Bandai Namco has unveiled the Bandai Namco has unveiled the system requirements for Tekken 8 fighting game .
Source: @Harada_TEKKEN
PC Bandai Namco multiplatform games

author: David Moss, Rose Village
title: Everybody Has a Story: Pacific island bomb tests resonate
text:
The other night I watched “Oppenheimer,” an extraordinarily powerful film. It reminded me of late 1960s and early 1970s, when I spent five years living in the Marshall Islands. I spent two as a Peace Corps volunteer and three more as a teacher at Marshall Islands High School, on contract with the U.S. Department of the Interior, which exercised administrative control there.
The United States conducted 67 atomic and hydrogen bomb tests in the Marshalls between 1946 and 1958, but we were not officially made aware of that. We also didn’t know about the possible health ramifications for anyone living on these islands. The bomb tests were in the news when we were little kids. All we remembered was Cold War “duck and cover” drills in our elementary schools.
The people of Bikini and Eniwetok, the far northwestern Marshallese atolls (rings of islands), were asked by the U.S. government to give up their homelands for these tests to further the cause of world peace. The Marshallese had been freed by the U.S. military from brutal Japanese occupation before and during World War II, and they were grateful. They thought they might be able to go back to their homes someday.
The fallout from previous atomic bomb tests was blown by trade winds into the uninhabited expanse of the Pacific Ocean. But fallout from the March 1, 1954, test on Bikini — the first one to use a hydrogen bomb — fell on inhabited islands.
Trending now Loading... The people on these islands had not been evacuated nor warned about the radioactive white ash falling from the sky. They thought it was snow, until it burned their skin.
The Bikini and Eniwetok atolls are now radioactive and unsafe for human habitation for a very, very long time. The people of all the affected islands now have higher rates of cancer than any other local group in the world. But in 1973, cement blocks made with radioactive sand and water were built on the main island of Bikini by Filipino construction crews. These crews were replaced every three months.
An ex-Peace Corps friend of mine even spent two years trying to re-grow coconut trees there. Using every growing methodology known then, he never got trees to grow higher than 2 feet. Then they died.
In spring 1973, I was living in Majuro, the capital of the Marshall Islands. My Peace Corps roommate, Ron, had never left and was working with a local businessman who was developing a hotel, a restaurant and shipping business. Ron and I met one afternoon for a beer at a local bar.
A man we didn’t know came in and we asked him to join us. We found out he was Carl Mydans, an award-winning photographer during the Great Depression, now working for Life magazine.
Mydans had just returned from a flight to Bikini atoll with various Marshallese elders and U.S. officials. The U.S. was preparing the atoll for resettlement.
Mydans told us that one of the Marshallese elders was the high chief. As their plane flew over the atoll, the chief looked down, looked at a map, pointed to a spot and asked, “Where’s this island?”
The officials looked at the map and looked down. “Well, it’s gone,” one said.
The chief stared down again. “Gone? How can that be? That was my family’s island. All my ancestors were buried there.”
The officials explained that the island had been destroyed in a bomb test. The chief looked down again. Then, Carl Mydans said, this 80-something-year old man started to cry. There was no way for him to understand what had happened, and no way for anyone on that plane to explain it to a man for whom land was everything.
So here we were, two 27-year-old ex-Peace Corps volunteers, still somewhat in the throes of 1960s “save the world” idealism, sitting at a bar on a Pacific island, having a Japanese beer with Carl Mydans, who had taken pictures of combat in Europe and the Pacific. He’d been captured by the Japanese and spent a year as a prisoner of war in the Philippines. He had captured the Japanese surrender aboard the U.S.S. Missouri.
And here, in a nondescript bar in the Marshall Islands, he cried. And so did Ron and I.

author: @WBRCnews
title: Wildfire leaves the preserve at McClellan Forestry with many acres destroyed
text:
ANNISTON, Ala. ( WBRC ) - City leaders in Anniston say they’ve fined some people for ignoring the city’s burn ban put in place because of the recent drought. That’s after Tuesday night, March 4, when a wildfire burned up to 100-acres at the wildlife oreserve at McClellan Forestry in Anniston.
Jackson Hodges with the City of Anniston says they started notifying neighbors just after 6 p.m. Tuesday night when the big fire began moving towards Veterans Memorial Parkway.
Hodges said Anniston firefighters joined Alabama Forestry Service firefighters to fight the big wildfire on the 900-acre wildlife preserve at McClellan Forestry. He said the fire burned up to 100-acres as crews worked to protect nearby buildings.
Hodges said all the rain Tuesday night helped provide some much needed relief to the dry conditions and exhausted firefighters who answered up to 60 calls this past weekend.
“It’s a real strain on these men and women and it puts them in danger, and we definitely don’t want that because they do such great work. This situation could’ve gotten out of hand quickly. I think people have seen how it has gotten out of hand in other states across the country and so we’re thankful, we have a top tier rated fire department,” said Hodges.
Hodges said the fire is under investigation while the burn ban in the city remains in place. He says anyone caught burning will be fined.
Get news alerts in the Apple App Store and Google Play Store or subscribe to our email newsletter here .

author: Florian Chevalier
title: Haute-Loire. Cent emplois supprimés chez le plus gros employeur privé du département
text:
Haute-Loire Valéo : cent emplois supprimés chez le plus gros employeur privé du département
L’équipementier automobile Valéo s’apprête à supprimer 100 emplois de cadres et de techniciens sur le site de Sainte-Florine en Haute-Loire selon la CGT. Une décision à laquelle s’opposent fermement les salariés. L’intersyndicale est convoquée ce vendredi 29 novembre.
Après la stupéfaction c’est la colère et l’incompréhension qui dominent chez Valéo. « Lors de notre dernière réunion avec la direction, il était question de 35 suppressions de postes. On a donc été très surpris d’apprendre que 100 emplois de cadres et techniciens allaient disparaître », commente Chantal Jouve, déléguée syndicale CGT au sein de l’entreprise, jointe par La Tribune-Le Progrès.
« C’est comme si on enlevait les poumons à l’usine »
Jeudi, [ 868 licenciements à l’échelle nationale](https://www.leprogres.fr/economie/2024/11/27/valeo-va-fermer-deux-usines-en-france-868-postes-supprimes) (chiffres de la direction, N.D.L.R) sur les huit sites Français que compte l’équipementier automobile ont été évoqués, dont cent sur le site brivadois. Le syndicat Force Ouvrière en annonce de son côté 1282 sur les 13 500 salariés travaillant dans l’entreprise à l’échelle de l’hexagone.
Selon Chantal Jouve, la décision est inconcevable d’autant que l’usine san-florinoise réalise des bénéfices. La confédération interprofessionnelle précise par ailleurs dans son tract : « L’équipementier automobile français a atteint ses objectifs avec une marge opérationnelle à 3,8 % du chiffre d’affaires contre 3,2 % en 2022. » « Avec la suppression de cadres, c‘est comme si on enlevait les poumons de l’usine. C’est contre-productif et cela va amener irrévocablement à une réaction en chaîne », ajoute Chantal Jouve.
« On va essayer de faire pression sur la direction »
À la suite des décisions prises par la direction concernant la suppression de 100 emplois sur le site de Sainte-Florine (*), plus gros employeur privé de Haute-Loire avec 600 salariés, la CGT a décidé de convoquer l’intersyndicale ce vendredi 29 novembre. « L’objectif est d’arriver à une entente entre les différents groupes pour défendre les salariés. En 2 ans, 2000 personnes ont quitté l’entreprise et ce n’est pas normal », réagit Chantal Jouve. « On va essayer de faire pression sur la direction. »
Durant le rassemblement prévu à 9h30, des tracts vont être distribués par les élus des syndicats. « Nous demandons à tous les salariés d’être vigilants et se joindre à toutes les actions que la CGT ou l’intersyndicale proposeront », peut-on lire dans la brochure.
(*) Contactée, la direction de Valéo Sainte-Florine n’a pas donné suite à notre appel.

author: Centre France
title: La transition écologique est en marche
text: Cravant. La transition écologique au programme.. Réunis à la salle polyvalente, sous la présidence de Frédéric Cuillerier, les élus du Pays Loire Beauce ont assisté à la réunion du comité syndical, mardi. Ils ont validé le programme de sensibilisation « Watty à l’école », proposé par le président. Financé par les fonds européens Leader et le Département, ce programme débutera en novembre avec l’objectif de rendre les enfants acteurs de la transition écologique, à l’école et à la maison, dans la continuité des ateliers initiés l’an dernier sur le territoire. Il se déclinera en trois ateliers thématiques par classe, jusqu’en juin 2025, et concernera un total de 129 classes, soit 2.900 élèves. Par ailleurs, avec la première édition de « Plant’action » (opération d’achat groupé de plants et de protection), le Pays Loire Beauce va pouvoir accompagner onze bénéficiaires (deux agriculteurs, deux associations, un particulier et six mairies). Au total, 2.500 plants seront, en partie, financés par la Région via le Contrat régional de solidarité territoriale. Les élus ont également échangé sur le projet de modification du Schéma régional d’aménagement, de développement durable et d’égalité des territoires, et son éventuel impact sur le développement du Pays Loire Beauce.
